title: RS22831
content: In 2007, Russian President Vladimir Putin faced the decision of stepping down or abolishing term limits. He endorsed Dmitriy Medvedev as his successor, reassuring Russians that the "Putin plan" would continue. Medvedev, known for implementing reforms, was appointed as the next president with Putin serving as prime minister. Dmitriy Medvedev, who had long served under Putin, was appointed as the next president in 2008. Four candidates registered for the election, with only three nominated by parties in the Duma. Opposition candidates faced challenges in gathering signatures, with some being denied registration by the Central Electoral Commission. Boris Nemtsov, nominated by the Union of Right Forces Party, withdrew from the campaign shortly after receiving approval to gather signatures. Boris Nemtsov, nominated by the Union of Right Forces Party, withdrew from the presidential campaign shortly after receiving approval from the CEC to gather signatures, citing government interference. Andrey Bogdanov, a candidate from the pro-Putin Democratic Party, successfully gathered two million signatures and was approved. Medvedev refused to debate other candidates, claiming their programs had no chance of implementation. Golos reported biased television coverage favoring Medvedev, leading to complaints of unequal coverage by Zyuganov and Zhirinovskiy. Putin and Medvedev presented long-term development programs during the campaign. Both Putin and Medvedev presented long-term development programs in 2008, focusing on stability, prosperity, and reforms in health, education, and the judiciary system by 2020. Medvedev emphasized the need for independent courts, media freedom, and respect for private property rights to drive economic development and ensure equal access to social support for all citizens. Medvedev won 70.28% of almost 75 million votes in the election, similar to Putin's percentage in 2004. Observers noted Zyuganov and Zhirinovskiy also benefitted from the election results. Bogdanov received fewer votes than expected and conceded defeat quickly. Zhirinovskiy conceded defeat quickly after receiving less than expected votes. He believed the election was conducted properly. Zyuganov claimed election "rigging" cost him 5%-10% of the vote. OSCE ODIHR declined to monitor the election due to Russian government restrictions. PACE monitoring group stated the election resembled a plebiscite on Putin's rule. Medvedev was given a solid mandate by the majority of Russians. The election process in Russia was criticized for not being free and fair, with concerns raised about the registration process for independent candidates and media coverage. Amendments to electoral legislation in 2005 limited observers to candidates' representatives and media only. Despite this, Golos sent observers to voting precincts, noting the presence of local government officials during vote counting. Putin congratulated Medvedev and mentioned plans to restructure the government before his inauguration. Putin congratulated Medvedev and mentioned plans to restructure the government before his inauguration. Medvedev stated that the election results endorsed Putin's policies and mandated them to continue for years to come. Putin directed ministries to work on detailed plans to implement 2020 development goals, including national project goals on urban policy, agricultural lands, and social sector reforms. He also emphasized promoting finished goods processing of natural resources, strengthening the home mortgage and banking systems, and streamlining rules for small businesses. Putin reminded ministers to find revenues to cover increased social benefits expenses. Some observers suggest Putin will retain power while Medvedev may have a ceremonial role. Putin emphasized the need to find revenues to cover increased social benefits expenses. Observers speculate that Putin will retain power while Medvedev may have a ceremonial role. Putin asserted that as prime minister, he would have substantial constitutional powers, including formulating budgets, monetary policy, and tackling various issues. Medvedev was chosen with the expectation that he would not reverse policies benefiting Putin's associates. Some predict that Medvedev may assert himself slowly as president, similar to how Putin moved against oligarchs in his first term. Some analysts predict that Medvedev may assert himself slowly as president, potentially challenging the "siloviki" power structure. There are suggestions that a power-sharing arrangement with Putin could lead to democratization. If Putin strengthens the ministerial system, other institutions like the legislature and judiciary may seek more autonomy, creating a better balance of powers. Concerns have been raised about potential clashes between Putin and Medvedev due to their different institutional roles. Putin's former chief of staff predicts clashes between Putin and Medvedev due to their different institutional roles. Concerns about inter-bureaucratic clashes paralyzing the government have been raised. Medvedev faces domestic challenges including sustaining the economic boom, rising inflation, terrorism, and civil disorder in the North Caucasus. Opposition marches have been met with force in Moscow, while pro-Putin groups protest alleged Western meddling. Medvedev, after the election, focused on foreign policy and accepted invitations to visit several countries. He urged Ukrainian President Yushchenko to pay the country's gas debt and faced international issues like new sanctions against Iranian uranium enrichment. President Bush emphasized the importance of a trustworthy relationship with the new Russian president. President Bush emphasized the importance of a trustworthy relationship with the new Russian president, focusing on common interests such as non-proliferation and Iranian nuclear issues. Disagreements between the United States and Russia include U.S. missile defenses in Eastern Europe, Kosovo's independence, and NATO enlargement. Putin threatened to target Poland, the Czech Republic, and Ukraine over these issues. Medvedev visited Serbia and supported its opposition to Kosovo's independence. Medvedev's involvement with Gazprom focused on economic relations with Europe, potentially influencing future chairman. Gazprom has been used as a political weapon by the Putin government, as seen in the reduction of gas supplies to Ukraine. Some believe Medvedev may work towards better ties with Europe, while others suggest he could emerge as a reformist president of Russia. Angela Merkel indicated continuity in Russia's relations with the West, with potential controversies persisting. Russian analyst Alexey Pushkov believes that U.S. policy analysts have focused too much on the negative aspects of Putin's authoritarianism, rather than Russia's economic stability. However, Putin's former economic advisor, Andrey Illarionov, warns that Medvedev has reversed democratization in Russia, labeling it a "siloviki dictatorship" with recent aggressive actions.
